   Assessment and Plan
   79 year-old male with a history of HTN, HLP, atrial fibrillation, h/o
   duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh
   MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff who developed acute
   abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free air and is now s/p
   right hemicolectomy and ileostomy
    # Septic shock
Presumed source of continued infection is persistent
   duodenal perforation and extravasation of gastric contents.  Patient is
   continuing to have fevers with wide differential including  infection,
   tumor, etc.  Overall trend is toward improvement though inability to
   diurese and need for pressors overnight is discouraging.  Will attempt
   to wean pressors and replete with blood products +/- albumin as needed.
   -Continue broad spectrum abx (vancomycin, meropenem, metronidazole,
   fluconazole)
   - ID reccs d/c vancomycin but will continue for now given likelihood of
   counts dropping soon
   - CT abdomen/pelvis today to r/o abscess
   - albumin and blood products as needed for intravascular volume
   - No further attempts to diurese today
   - Keep Hct>25, Plt.>50
   - Hct, Plt, Coags q8hrs
   # Respiratory Failure: both hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure
   in the setting of sepsis.  CXR with pulmonary edema and pleural
   effusions.  Also, could be developing ARDS in the setting of perforated
   bowel.   Currently on stable ventilator settings.  S/p bronch on [**3-22**]
   for right lobar collapse but no mucous plug seen; aeration improved
   after advancement of ETT 2 cm (was at level of vocal chords).  S/p
   bronch on [**3-23**] for decreased right lung size but mucous plug again
   absent.  Bronched again today w/o clear plugging or collapse.  Have
   attempted to wean to PS *2 but patient has not been able to tolerate
   due to increased work of breathing and dyspnea.
   - continue current vent settings but decrease FiO2 given PaO2 of 170
   today
   - will place pigtail catheter in left chest given increasing pleural
   effusions and ?parapneumonic effusion
   - daily ABGs
   # Coagulopathy:  meets parameters for DIC based on elevated FDP but not
   clinically in DIC given absence of diffuse bleeding.  Will empirically
   treat for DIC because high risk.
   - continue blood, FFP, blood transfusions as needed
   - coags, hct, and platlets q12hr with goal INR<=1.6
   - s/p vitamin K 5mg IV x 2 on [**2157-3-23**]
   # Hemicolectomy and duodenal perforation:  Sepsis management as above,
   transfusion parameters as above.
   # [**Last Name (un) 2406**]:  ATN with muddy brown casts in urine.  Was oliguric on [**2157-3-22**]
   but urine output increasing as of [**2157-3-23**].  Concern initially for
   worsening kidney function and possible need for dialysis but UOP
   improving.  Likely experienced ATN from hypoperfusion in setting of
   sepsis.
   - f/u renal reccs
   - monitor lytes
   - Will decrease vanc to 750mg q12h and check trough in AM (trough today
   appropriate at 20, will continue dosing and recheck level in AM)
   # C.diff: Diagnosed in setting of abdominal pain and relatively soon
   interval development of septic picture.
   - cont with IV flagyl
   - surgery following
   # AML/Leukemia cutis:  S/p dacogen.  Likely counts will begin to drop
   further in the next few days per oncology.
   - tx to keep HCT>25 based on consultation with surgery
   - tx to keep plts >50K
   - BMT recs
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: on arrival, very tachycardic to
   130-150s.  Likely all response to being septic and post operatively.
   Norepinephrine also likely culprit.  Cards consulted and do not think
   TEE followed by cardioversion indicated at this time. If becomes
   acutely unstable, consider emergent cardioversion without TEE followed
   by amio gtt.  HR stabilizing to 80-100 now.
   - hold nodal agents for now
   - no amio for now- not anticoagulated so concern for embolic even if
   spontaneously converts
   # Sacral deep tissue injury:  Wound nurses following.
   # FEN: NPO for now; IVFs as above; TPN
   - replete lytes PRN
   # Access: RIJ, left radial a-line.  left PICC
   # Comm: Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4140**]

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer surgery. He was admitted with leukemia cutis/acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and left thigh MRSA cellulitis. During his hospital course, he developed Clostridium difficile (c.diff) infection and now presents with acute abdominal pain on [**3-21**] after undergoing a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy.

The patient's current condition includes septic shock presumed to be due to a persistent duodenal perforation and extravasation of gastric contents. He continues to have fevers with a wide differential including infection, tumor, etc. Despite overall improvement, the patient's inability to diurese and the need for pressors overnight are concerning. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are being continued, and a CT abdomen/pelvis is planned to rule out abscess formation.

The patient also has respiratory failure, both hypercarbic and hypoxemic, in the setting of sepsis. A chest X-ray shows pulmonary edema and pleural effusions. The patient has been bronchoscoped multiple times for right lobar collapse but no mucous plug has been seen. The patient's current ventilator settings will be continued, and FiO2 will be decreased due to a PaO2 of 170 today. A pigtail catheter will be placed in

   79 year-old male with a history of HTN, HLP, atrial fibrillation, h/o
   duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh

Presumed source of continued infection is persistent

   continuing to have fevers with wide differential including  infection,

   -Continue broad spectrum abx (vancomycin, meropenem, metronidazole,
   fluconazole)
   - ID reccs d/c vancomycin but will continue for now given likelihood of
   counts dropping soon
   - CT abdomen/pelvis today to r/o abscess
   - albumin and blood products as needed for intravascular volume
   - No further attempts to diurese today
   - Keep Hct>25, Plt.>50
   - Hct, Plt, Coags q8hrs
   # Respiratory Failure: both hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure
   in the setting of sepsis.  CXR with pulmonary edema and pleural
   effusions.  Also, could be developing ARDS in the setting of perforated
   bowel.   Currently on stable ventilator settings.  S/p bronch on [**3-22**]
   for right lobar collapse but no mucous plug seen; aeration improved
   after advancement of ETT 2 cm (was at level of vocal chords).  S/p
   bronch on [**3-23**] for decreased right lung size but mucous plug again
   absent.  Bronched again today w/o clear plugging or collapse.  Have
   attempted to wean to PS *2 but patient has not been able to tolerate
   due to increased work of breathing and dyspnea.
   - continue current vent settings but decrease FiO2 given PaO2 of 170

   - will place pigtail catheter in left chest given increasing pleural

   - f/u renal reccs
   - monitor lytes
   - Will decrease vanc to 750mg q12h and check trough in AM (trough today
   appropriate at 20, will continue dosing and recheck evel in AM)
   # C.diff: Diagnosed in setting of abdominal pain and relatively soon
   interval development of septic picture.
   - cont with IV flagyl
   - surgery following
   # AML/Leukemia cutis:  S/p dacogen.  Likely counts will begin to drop
   further in the next few days per oncology.
   - tx to keep HCT>25 based on consultation with surgery
   - tx to keep plts >50K

   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: on arrival, very tachycardic to

Summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer surgery. He was admitted with leukemia cutis/acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and left thigh MRSA cellulitis. During his hospital course, he developed c.difficile, acute abdominal pain, and free air on CT, leading to a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. He is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient has persistent duodenal perforation, which could be the source of continued infection. He is experiencing fevers, indicating ongoing sepsis. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are being administered to cover for various potential pathogens.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing both hypercarbic and hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely due to sepsis. He has pulmonary edema and pleural effusions on chest X-ray, and there is a concern for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) secondary to the perforated bowel.

3. Coagulopathy: The patient meets the criteria for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) based on elevated fibrin degradation products, although he does not exhibit clinical signs of DIC. Empirical treatment for DIC is being provided due to his high risk.

4. Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): The patient has muddy brown casts in his urine

   Assessment and Plan
   79 year-old male with a history of HTN, HLP, atrial fibrillation, h/o
   duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh
   MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff who developed acute
   abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free air and is now s/p
   right hemicolectomy and ileostomy
   # Septic shock: Presumed source of continued infection is persistent
   duodenal perforation and extravasation of gastric contents.  Patient is
   continuing to have fevers with wide differential including  infection,
   tumor, etc.  Overall trend is toward improvement though inability to
   diurese and need for pressors overnight is discouraging.  Will attempt
   to wean pressors and replete with blood products +/- albumin as needed.
   -Continue broad spectrum abx (vancomycin, meropenem, metronidazole,
   fluconazole)
   - ID reccs d/c vancomycin but will continue for now given likelihood of
   counts dropping soon
   - CT abdomen/pelvis today to r/o abscess
   - albumin and blood products as needed for intravascular volume
   - No further attempts to diurese today
   - Keep Hct>25, Plt.>50
   - Hct, Plt, Coags q8hrs
   # Respiratory Failure: both hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure
   in the setting of sepsis.  CXR with pulmonary edema and pleural
   effusions.  Also, could be developing ARDS in the setting of perforated
   bowel.   Currently on stable ventilator settings.  S/p bronch on [**3-22**]
   for right lobar collapse but no mucous plug seen; aeration improved
   after advancement of ETT 2 cm (was at level of vocal chords).  S/p
   bronch on [**3-23**] for decreased right lung size but mucous plug again
   absent.  Bronched again today w/o clear plugging or collapse.  Have
   attempted to wean to PS *2 but patient has not been able to tolerate
   due to increased work of breathing and dyspnea.
   - continue current vent settings but decrease FiO2 given PaO2 of 170
   today
   - will place pigtail catheter in left chest given increasing pleural
   effusions and ?parapneumonic effusion
   - daily ABGs
   # Coagulopathy:  meets parameters for DIC based on elevated FDP but not
   clinically in DIC given absence of diffuse bleeding.  Will empirically
   treat for DIC because high risk.
   - continue blood, FFP, blood transfusions as needed
   - coags, hct, and platlets q12hr with goal INR<=1.6
   - s/p vitamin K 5mg IV x 2 on [**2157-3-23**]
   # Hemicolectomy and duodenal perforation:  Sepsis management as above,
   transfusion parameters as above.
   # [**Last Name (un) 2406**]:  ATN with muddy brown casts in urine.  Was oliguric on [**2157-3-22**]
   but urine output increasing as of [**2157-3-23**].  Concern initially for
   worsening kidney function and possible need for dialysis but UOP
   improving.  Likely experienced ATN from hypoperfusion in setting of
   sepsis.
   - f/u renal reccs
   - monitor lytes
   - Will decrease vanc to 750mg q12h and check trough in AM (trough today
   appropriate at 20, will continue dosing and recheck level in AM)
   # C.diff: Diagnosed in setting of abdominal pain and relatively soon
   interval development of septic picture.
   - cont with IV flagyl
   - surgery following
   # AML/Leukemia cutis:  S/p dacogen.  Likely counts will begin to drop
   further in the next few days per oncology.
   - tx to keep HCT>25 based on consultation with surgery
   - tx to keep plts >50K
   - BMT recs
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: on arrival, very tachycardic to
   130-150s.  Likely all response to being septic and post operatively.
   Norepinephrine also likely culprit.  Cards consulted and do not think
   TEE followed by cardioversion indicated at this time. If becomes
   acutely unstable, consider emergent cardioversion without TEE followed
   by amio gtt.  HR stabilizing to 80-100 now.
   - hold nodal agents for now
   - no amio for now- not anticoagulated so concern for embolic even if
   spontaneously converts
   # Sacral deep tissue injury:  Wound nurses following.
   # FEN: NPO for now; IVFs as above; TPN
   - replete lytes PRN
   # Access: RIJ, left radial a-line.  left PICC

Summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and previous duodenal ulcer surgery. He was admitted with leukemia cutis/acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and left thigh MRSA cellulitis. During his hospital course, he developed Clostridium difficile infection and now presents with acute abdominal pain. A CT scan revealed free air and he underwent a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. The patient continues to have fevers, and his condition is complicated by septic shock, respiratory failure, coagulopathy, acute tubular necrosis (ATN), C. difficile infection, AML, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and sacral deep tissue injury.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Septic Shock: The patient is at risk for continued infection due to persistent duodenal perforation and extravasation of gastric contents. Close monitoring of vital signs, fluid status, and blood cultures is necessary.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has both hypercarbic and hypoxemic respiratory failure. Weaning off the ventilator may be challenging due to increased work of breathing and dyspnea. Daily ABGs and pulmonary support should be continued.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient meets parameters for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) but does not exhibit clinical signs. Empirical treatment for DIC is recommended due to high

Summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer status post surgery. He was admitted with leukemia cutis/acute myeloid leukemia (AML), left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and hospital course complicated by Clostridium difficile infection. 

The patient developed acute abdominal pain on [3-21] with a CT scan showing free air, indicating a perforation. He subsequently underwent a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. He is currently experiencing septic shock, presumed to be due to the persistent duodenal perforation and extravasation of gastric contents. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 101.2°F, heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure of 34/33 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. He is on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, set tidal volume of 550 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O, fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%, and respiratory system compliance (RSBI) deferred due to PEEP > 10. His arterial blood gas (ABG) results show pH of 7.37, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 51 mmHg, partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 348 mmHg, and oxygen consumption (VO2) of 26.0%. 

The patient's physical examination reveals general appearance of being overweight/obese, eyes/conjunctiva as pinpoint (PERRL), normocephalic endotracheal tube, and nasogastric (NG) tube. His cardiovascular assessment shows normal heart sounds (S1 and S2), peripheral pulses, and no signs of peripheral edema. His respiratory assessment indicates clear breath sounds with diminished breath sounds at the left base. 

Abdominal examination reveals soft, non-tender abdomen with bowel sounds present, ostomy present, and multiple Jackson-Pratt (JP) drains. Extremity examination shows edema of both lower extremities, rated as 3+ edema bilaterally. Neurologic assessment reveals the patient to be attentive, following simple commands, responding to verbal stimuli, and showing purposeful movements. 

Laboratory results show leukocyte count (WBC) of 8.2 thousand/mm3, hematocrit (Hct) of 26.4%, platelet count (Plt) of 52 thousand/mm3, creatinine (Cr) of 1.1 mg/dL, total carbon dioxide (TCO2) of 29 mmol/L, glucose level of 127 mg/dL, and lactic acid level of 1.1 mmol/L. The patient's blood cultures are positive for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). 

The patient's assessment includes impaired skin integrity, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, cancer (malignant neoplasm), respiratory failure, coagulopathy, hemicolectomy and duodenal perforation, acute tubular necrosis (ATN), Clostridium difficile infection, acute myeloid leukemia/leukemia cutis, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response

   79 year-old male with a history of HTN, HLP, atrial fibrillation, h/o
   duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh
   MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff who developed acute
   abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free air and is now s/p
   right hemicolectomy and ileostomy
   # Septic shock: Presumably due to continued infection and persistent
   duodenal perforation with extravasation of gastric contents.  Patient
   is continuing to have fevers with wide differential including
   infection, tumor, etc.  Overall trend is toward improvement.  We will
   attempt to wean pressors and replete with blood products +/- albumin as
   needed.  CT on [**2157-3-30**] showed persistent duodetal perforation but no
   clear evidence of abscess.
   -Continue broad spectrum abx (vancomycin d1=[**3-22**], meropenem d1=[**3-22**],
   metronidazole d1=[**3-21**], fluconazole d1=[**3-21**])
   - ID reccs d/c vancomycin but will continue for now per surgery given
   likelihood of counts dropping soon
   - albumin and blood products as needed for intravascular volume
   - lasix gtt with pressors, will attempt to get 1L negative today
   - Keep Hct>25, Plt.>50
   - Hct, Plt, Coags q12hrs
   - If fevers do not resolve, consider evaluation for drug fever
could
   hold vancomycin
   # Respiratory Failure: both hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure
   in the setting of sepsis.  CXR with pulmonary edema and pleural
   effusions.  Also, could be developing ARDS in the setting of perforated
   bowel.   Improved aeration of the left lung after pleural drain
   placement yesterday and patient did well on PS trial.  S/p bronch on
   [**3-23**] for decreased right lung size but mucous plug again absent.
   Bronched again today w/o clear plugging or collapse.
   - IP to drain right side effusion today, will send for studies, CXR
   afterward and attempt [**6-7**] trial if tolerates
   - daily ABGs
   # Coagulopathy:  meets parameters for DIC based on elevated FDP but not
   clinically in DIC given absence of diffuse bleeding.  Will empirically
   treat for DIC because high risk.
   - continue blood, FFP, blood transfusions as needed
   - coags, hct, and platlets q12hr with goal INR<=1.6
   - s/p vitamin K 5mg IV x 2 on [**2157-3-23**]
   # Hemicolectomy and duodenal perforation:  Sepsis management as above,
   transfusion parameters as above.
   # [**Last Name (un) 2406**]:  ATN with muddy brown casts in urine.  Was oliguric on [**2157-3-22**]
   but urine output increasing as of [**2157-3-23**].  Concern initially for
   worsening kidney function and possible need for dialysis but UOP
   improving.  Likely experienced ATN from hypoperfusion in setting of
   sepsis.
   - f/u renal reccs
   - monitor lytes
   - Cont vanc to 750mg q12h and check trough in AM (trough appears to be
   stable at 20)
   # C.diff: Diagnosed in setting of abdominal pain and relatively soon
   interval development of septic picture.
   - cont with IV flagyl (d1=[**3-21**])
   - surgery following
   # AML/Leukemia cutis:  S/p dacogen.
   - tx to keep HCT>25 based on consultation with surgery
   - tx to keep plts >50K (transfuse this AM)
   - BMT reccs
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: on arrival, very tachycardic to
   130-150s.  Likely all response to being septic and post operatively.
   Norepinephrine also likely culprit.  Cards consulted and do not think
   TEE followed by cardioversion indicated at this time. If becomes
   acutely unstable, consider emergent cardioversion without TEE followed
   by amio gtt.  HR stabilizing to 80-100 now.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and previous duodenal ulcer surgery. He was admitted with leukemia cutis/acute myeloid leukemia (AML), left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and subsequently developed acute abdominal pain on [3-21] with a CT scan showing free air, indicating a perforation. The patient underwent right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. He is now in the ICU with multiple medical complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient has been diagnosed with septic shock due to continued infection and persistent duodenal perforation with extravasation of gastric contents. He has fevers with a wide differential including infection, tumor, etc.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing both hypercarbic and hypoxemic respiratory failure in the setting of sepsis. This could be due to pulmonary edema, pleural effusions, and the development of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) in the setting of perforated bowel.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient meets parameters for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) based on elevated fibrin degradation products but does not have clinical signs of DIC. However, he is being treated empirically for DIC due to high risk.
4. Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): The patient has muddy brown casts in his urine

 IMPAIRED SKIN INTEGRITY
 SEPSIS, SEVERE (WITH ORGAN DYSFUNCTION)
 CANCER (MALIGNANT NEOPLASM), OTHER
   79 year-old male with a history of HTN, HLP, atrial fibrillation, h/o
   duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh
   MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff who developed acute
   abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free air and is now s/p
   right hemicolectomy and ileostomy
    # Septic shock: Presumably due to continued infection and persistent
   duodenal perforation with extravasation of gastric contents.  Patient
   is continuing to have fevers with wide differential including
   infection, tumor, etc.  Overall trend is toward improvement.  We will
   attempt to wean pressors and replete with blood products +/- albumin as
   needed.  CT on [**2157-3-30**] showed persistent duodetal perforation but no
   clear evidence of abscess.
   -Continue broad spectrum abx meropenem d1=[**3-22**], metronidazole d1=[**3-21**],
   fluconazole d1=[**3-21**]
   - ID reccs d/c vancomycin- done
   - albumin and blood products as needed for intravascular volume
   - lasix gtt with pressors, will attempt to get 1L negative today
   - Keep Hct>25, Plt.>50
   - Hct, Plt, Coags q12hrs
   - If fevers do not resolve, consider evaluation for drug fever
could
   hold vancomycin
   # Respiratory Failure: both hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure
   in the setting of sepsis.  CXR with pulmonary edema and pleural
   effusions.  Also, could be developing ARDS in the setting of perforated
   bowel.   Improved aeration of the left lung after pleural drain
   placement yesterday and patient did well on PS trial.  S/p bronch on
   [**3-23**] for decreased right lung size but mucous plug again absent.
   Bronched again today w/o clear plugging or collapse.
   - IP to drain right side effusion today, will send for studies, CXR
   afterward and attempt [**6-7**] trial if tolerates
   - daily ABGs
   # Coagulopathy:  meets parameters for DIC based on elevated FDP but not
   clinically in DIC given absence of diffuse bleeding.  Will empirically
   treat for DIC because high risk.
   - continue blood, FFP, blood transfusions as needed
   - coags, hct, and platlets q12hr with goal INR<=1.6
   - s/p vitamin K 5mg IV x 2 on [**2157-3-23**]
   # Hemicolectomy and duodenal perforation:  Sepsis management as above,
   transfusion parameters as above.
   # [**Last Name (un) 2406**]:  ATN with muddy brown casts in urine.  Was oliguric on [**2157-3-22**]
   but urine output increasing as of [**2157-3-23**].  Concern initially for
   worsening kidney function and possible need for dialysis but UOP
   improving.  Likely experienced ATN from hypoperfusion in setting of
   sepsis.
   - f/u renal reccs
   - monitor lytes
   - Cont vanc to 750mg q12h and check trough in AM (trough appears to be
   stable at 20)
   # C.diff: Diagnosed in setting of abdominal pain and relatively soon
   interval development of septic picture.
   - cont with IV flagyl (d1=[**3-21**])
   - surgery following
   # AML/Leukemia cutis:  S/p dacogen.
   - tx to keep HCT>25 based on consultation with surgery
   - tx to keep plts >50K (transfuse this AM)
   - BMT reccs
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: on arrival, very tachycardic to
   130-150s.  Likely all response to being septic and post operatively.
   Norepinephrine also likely culprit.  Cards consulted and do not think
   TEE followed by cardioversion indicated at this time. If becomes
   acutely unstable, consider emergent cardioversion without TEE followed
   by amio gtt.  HR stabilizing to 80-100 now.
   - hold nodal agents for now
   - no amio for now- not anticoagulated so concern for embolic even if
   spontaneously converts
    # Sacral deep tissue injury:  Wound nurses following.
    # FEN: NPO for now; IVFs as above; TPN
   - replete lytes PRN
    # Access: RIJ,  left midline
    # Comm: Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4140**]

He was admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and c.diff. The patient developed acute abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with a CT scan showing free air, indicating a possible duodenal perforation. He subsequently underwent a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy.

The patient's current condition is summarized as follows:
- Impaired skin integrity: The patient has areas of impaired skin integrity, likely due to the MRSA infection and c.diff.

- Respiratory failure: The patient is experiencing both hypercarbic and hypoxemic respiratory failure, possibly due to sepsis and a perforated bowel. There is also evidence of pulmonary edema and pleural effusions on the chest X-ray.
- Coagulopathy: The patient has an elevated FDP level, suggesting disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), although he does not exhibit clinical signs of DIC. He is being empirically treated for DIC due to the high risk.
- Hemicolectomy and duodenal perfor

   Assessment and Plan
 IMPAIRED SKIN INTEGRITY
 SEPSIS, SEVERE (WITH ORGAN DYSFUNCTION)
 CANCER (MALIGNANT NEOPLASM), OTHER
   79 year-old male with a history of HTN, HLP, atrial fibrillation, h/o
   duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh
   MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff who developed acute
   abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free air and is now s/p
   right hemicolectomy and ileostomy
    # Septic shock: Presumably due to continued infection and persistent
   duodenal perforation with extravasation of intestinal contents.
   Patient is continuing to have fevers with wide differential including
   infection, tumor, etc.  Overall trend is toward improvement.  We will
   attempt to wean pressors and replete with blood products +/- albumin as
   needed.  CT on [**2157-3-30**] showed persistent duodetal perforation but no
   clear evidence of abscess.
   -Continue broad spectrum abx meropenem d1=[**3-22**], metronidazole d1=[**3-21**],
   fluconazole d1=[**3-21**]
   - ID reccs d/c vancomycin- done
   - albumin and blood products as needed for intravascular volume
   - lasix gtt turned off this am as pt already >2L neg on day
   - titrate levo PRN
   - Keep Hct>25, Plt.>50
   - Hct, Plt, Coags q12hrs
   # Respiratory Failure: both hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure
   in the setting of sepsis.  CXR with pulmonary edema and pleural
   effusions.  Improved aeration of the left lung after pleural drain
   placement and on right side after thoracentesis.  S/p bronch on [**3-23**]
   for decreased right lung size but mucous plug again absent.  Bronched
   again [**4-1**] w/o clear plugging or collapse.
   - attempt extubation today with family understanding that pt not
   eligible for reintubation given coexisting medical probs
   # Coagulopathy:  On [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] admission  met parameters for DIC based on
   elevated FDP but not clinically in DIC given absence of diffuse
   bleeding.
   - continue blood, FFP, blood transfusions as needed
   - coags, hct, and platlets q12hr with goal INR<=1.6
   - s/p vitamin K 5mg IV x 2 on [**2157-3-23**]
   # Hemicolectomy and duodenal perforation:  Sepsis management as above,
   transfusion parameters as above. Collaborating with surgical team
   # [**Last Name (un) 2406**]:  ATN with muddy brown casts in urine.  Was oliguric on [**2157-3-22**]
   but urine output increasing as of [**2157-3-23**].  Concern initially for
   worsening kidney function and possible need for dialysis but UOP
   improving.  Likely experienced ATN from hypoperfusion in setting of
   sepsis.
   - f/u renal reccs
   - monitor lytes
   # C.diff: Diagnosed in setting of abdominal pain and relatively soon
   interval development of septic picture.
   - cont with IV flagyl (d1=[**3-21**])
   - surgery following
   # AML/Leukemia cutis:  S/p dacogen.
   - tx to keep HCT>25 based on consultation with surgery
   - tx to keep plts >50K (transfuse this AM)
   - BMT reccs
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: on arrival, very tachycardic to
   130-150s.  Likely all response to being septic and post operatively.
   Norepinephrine also likely culprit.  Cards consulted and do not think
   TEE followed by cardioversion indicated at this time. If becomes
   acutely unstable, consider emergent cardioversion without TEE followed
   by amio gtt.  HR stable over last several days.
   - hold nodal agents for now
   - no amio for now- not anticoagulated so concern for embolic even if
   spontaneously converts
    # Sacral deep tissue injury:  Wound nurses following.
    # FEN: NPO for now; IVFs as above; TPN
   - replete lytes PRN
    # Access: RIJ,  left midline

Summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and h/o duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and hospital course complicated by c.diff who developed acute abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free air and is now s/p right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. 

The patient is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications. The summary of the progress note indicates that the patient has impaired skin integrity, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, cancer (malignant neoplasm), respiratory failure, coagulopathy, hemicolectomy and duodenal perforation, acute tubular necrosis (ATN), Clostridium difficile infection, acute myeloid leukemia/leukemia cutis, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, sacral deep tissue injury, and feeding tube placement.

The patient's current condition is as follows:
- Vital signs: Tcurrent: 36.9°C, HR: 88 bpm, BP: 101/60 mmHg, RR: 15 insp/min, SpO2: 100%
- Hemodynamic monitoring: Norepinephrine infusion at 0.17 mcg/kg/min
- Fluid balance: Total in: 5,302 mL, total out: 6,548 mL, urine output

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension (HTN), hyperlipidemia (HLP), atrial fibrillation, and a past surgical history of duodenal ulcer surgery. He was admitted with leukemia cutis/acute myeloid leukemia (AML), left thigh methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) cellulitis, and hospital-acquired Clostridium difficile (c.diff). The patient developed acute abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with a CT scan showing free air, leading to a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy.

24-hour Events:
- Received two units of platelets in the morning for drainage of right-sided pleural effusion (thoracentesis removed 1.2 L fluid). Prior to platelets, there was diffuse oozing of blood from the colostomy site and some IV sites, which somewhat resolved. Hematocrit (Hct) checked from drain was <2%.
- A-line disconnected as it was not working.
- Thoracentesis with 1.2 L of fluid removed (unable to place drain because collection too posterior).
- Got one packet of platelets in the evening for Plt 29, deferred blood given overall goal to get the patient negative.
- Weaned from [**11-12**] to [**11-7**] in the morning and did well until late afternoon

   79 year-old male with a history of HTN, HLP, atrial fibrillation, h/o
   duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh
   MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff who developed acute
   abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free air and is now s/p
   right hemicolectomy and ileostomy
   # Septic shock: Presumably due to continued infection and persistent
   duodenal perforation with extravasation of intestinal contents.
   Patient is continuing to have fevers with wide differential including
   infection, tumor, etc.  Overall trend is toward improvement.  We will
   attempt to wean pressors and replete with blood products +/- albumin as
   needed.  CT on [**2157-3-30**] showed persistent duodetal perforation but no
   clear evidence of abscess.   In contact with surgery (pager [**Numeric Identifier 4453**]).
   - Continue broad spectrum abx meropenem d1=[**3-22**] (day 13), metronidazole
   d1=[**3-21**] (day 14), fluconazole d1=[**3-21**] (day 14)
   - ID reccs d/c vancomycin- done
   - albumin and blood products as needed for intravascular volume
   - restart lasix gtt
   - titrate levo PRN
   - Keep Hct>25, Plt.>50
   - Hct, Plt, Coags q12hrs
   # Respiratory Failure: both hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure
   in the setting of sepsis.  CXR with pulmonary edema and pleural
   effusions.  Improved aeration of the left lung after pleural drain
   placement and on right side after thoracentesis.  S/p bronch on [**3-23**]
   for decreased right lung size but mucous plug again absent.  Bronched
   again [**4-1**] w/o clear plugging or collapse.   Extubated successfully on
   [**4-2**].
   - continue supplemental oxygen
   - consider prn nebs, though does not carry a diagnosis of COPD
   # Coagulopathy:  On [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] admission  met parameters for DIC based on
   elevated FDP but not clinically in DIC given absence of diffuse
   bleeding.
   - continue blood, FFP, blood transfusions as needed
   - coags, hct, and platlets q12hr with goal INR<=1.6
   - s/p vitamin K 5mg IV x 2 on [**2157-3-23**]
   # Hemicolectomy and duodenal perforation:  Sepsis management as above,
   transfusion parameters as above. Collaborating with surgical team
   # [**Last Name (un) 2406**]:  ATN with muddy brown casts in urine.  Was oliguric on [**2157-3-22**]
   but urine output increasing as of [**2157-3-23**].  Concern initially for
   worsening kidney function and possible need for dialysis but UOP
   improving.  Likely experienced ATN from hypoperfusion in setting of
   sepsis.
   - f/u renal reccs
   - monitor lytes
   # C.diff: Diagnosed in setting of abdominal pain and relatively soon
   interval development of septic picture.
   - cont with IV flagyl (d1=[**3-21**]; day 14)
   - surgery following
   # AML/Leukemia cutis:  S/p dacogen.
   - tx to keep HCT>25 based on consultation with surgery
   - tx to keep plts >50K (transfuse this AM)
   - BMT reccs
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: on arrival, very tachycardic to
   130-150s.  Likely all response to being septic and post operatively.
   Norepinephrine also likely culprit.  Cards consulted and do not think
   TEE followed by cardioversion indicated at this time. If becomes
   acutely unstable, consider emergent cardioversion without TEE followed
   by amio gtt.  HR stable over last several days.
   - hold nodal agents for now
   - no amio for now- not anticoagulated so concern for embolic even if
   spontaneously converts
   # Sacral deep tissue injury:  Wound nurses following.
   # FEN: NPO for now; IVFs as above; TPN
   - replete lytes PRN

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer surgery. He was admitted with leukemia cutis/acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and left thigh MRSA cellulitis. During his hospital course, he developed Clostridium difficile infection and underwent a right hemicolectomy due to acute abdominal pain with a CT scan showing free air. The patient is now extubated and receiving supplemental oxygen.

Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is presumed to have septic shock due to continued infection and persistent duodenal perforation with extravasation of intestinal contents. He has had fevers with a wide differential including infection, tumor, etc.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient initially required mechanical ventilation but is now extubated. He experienced hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure in the setting of sepsis. A chest X-ray showed pulmonary edema and pleural effusions. Improved aeration of the left lung after pleural drain placement and on the right side after thoracentesis was observed. The patient underwent bronchoscopy for decreased right lung size but mucous plug was absent. Another bronchoscopy was performed without clear plugging or collapse.

3. Coagulopathy: The patient had elevated FDP levels but did not meet clinical criteria for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Summary:
The patient has a history of perforated abdomen and is currently in the ICU. They are extubated and receiving low-dose norepinephrine. The patient's hemodynamics are stable, and they have been successfully extubated. However, there are several potential medical complications that can arise. These include respiratory failure due to inadequate oxygenation, hemodynamic instability due to fluid overload, coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia, abdominal perforation with ongoing management of the open abdomen, and impaired skin integrity.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient may experience respiratory failure if they are unable to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation. Close monitoring of respiratory parameters, such as oxygen saturation (SpO2) and peak inspiratory pressure (PIP), is necessary. If the patient's respiratory status worsens, reintubation may be required.

2. Hemodynamic Instability: The patient's intravascular volume is overloaded, leading to hypotension and the need for vasopressor support. Monitoring of blood pressure, central venous pressure (CVP), and urine output is important. Adjustments in fluid management and vasopressor therapy should be made accordingly.

3. Coagulopathy and Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a coagulopathic state with thrombocytopenia. Platelet transfusion should be given as needed for procedures or active bleeding. Regular monitoring of coagulation

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.9°C (98.5°F), heart rate of 111 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 62-95/54-79 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. 3. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathic state indicated by low platelet count and prolonged clotting times. This increases the risk of bleeding, especially during invasive procedures.
4. Infection: The patient is on broad-spectrum antibiotics due to sepsis. There is a risk of antibiotic resistance or adverse drug reactions.

Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a chief complaint of a perforated abdomen. The patient has been in the ICU and is currently experiencing several medical complications.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient was successfully extubated last night, but there is a concern about re-intubation as per family wishes.
2. Hemodynamics: The patient's intravascular volume is low, but overall body volume is overloaded. The patient is receiving norepinephrine to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 60, while also trying to maintain adequate oxygenation.
3. Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML): The patient has coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia. Platelet transfusion is only being given as needed for procedures or active bleeding.
4. Abdominal Perforation: The patient still has an open abdomen and no plans for intervention have been discussed. Dr. [Last Name (STitle) 4443] was consulted on rounds this morning.
5. Other issues: These include ICU care, nutrition, glycemic control, lines, prophylaxis (DVT and stress ulcer), communication with the family, code status (DNR), and disposition in the ICU.

- Heart rate: 111 bpm (with a range of 95-119 bpm)
- Blood pressure: 95

   Assessment and Plan
   79 year-old male with a history of HTN, HLP, atrial fibrillation, h/o
   duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh
   MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff now s/p right
   hemicolectomy and ileostomy
   # Septic shock: Presumably due to continued infection and persistent
   duodenal perforation with extravasation of intestinal contents.
   Patient is continuing to have fevers with wide differential including
   infection, tumor, etc.  Overall trend is toward improvement.  We will
   attempt to wean pressors and replete with blood products +/- albumin as
   needed.  CT on [**2157-3-30**] showed persistent duodetal perforation but no
   clear evidence of abscess.   In contact with surgery (pager [**Numeric Identifier 4453**]).
   - Continue broad spectrum abx meropenem d1=[**3-22**] (day 13), metronidazole
   d1=[**3-21**] (day 14), fluconazole d1=[**3-21**] (day 14)
   - ID reccs d/c vancomycin- done
   - albumin and blood products as needed for intravascular volume
   - restart lasix gtt
   - titrate levo PRN
   - Keep Hct>25, Plt.>50 per [**Doctor First Name **] recs
   - Hct, Plt, Coags q12hrs
   # Respiratory Failure: both hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure
   in the setting of sepsis.  CXR with pulmonary edema and pleural
   effusions.  Improved aeration of the left lung after pleural drain
   placement and on right side after thoracentesis.  S/p bronch on [**3-23**]
   for decreased right lung size but mucous plug again absent.  Bronched
   again [**4-1**] w/o clear plugging or collapse.   Extubated successfully on
   [**4-2**].
   - continue supplemental oxygen
   - consider prn nebs, though does not carry a diagnosis of COPD
   # Coagulopathy:  On [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] admission  met parameters for DIC based on
   elevated FDP but not clinically in DIC given absence of diffuse
   bleeding.  No longer has evidence of DIC on labs.
   - continue blood transfusions as needed
   - coags, hct, and platlets q12hr with goal INR<=1.6
   - s/p vitamin K 5mg IV x 2 on [**2157-3-23**]
   # Hemicolectomy and duodenal perforation:  Sepsis management as above,
   transfusion parameters as above. Collaborating with surgical team
   # [**Last Name (un) 2406**]:  ATN with muddy brown casts in urine.  Was oliguric on [**2157-3-22**]
   but urine output increasing as of [**2157-3-23**].  Concern initially for
   worsening kidney function and possible need for dialysis but UOP
   improving.  Likely experienced ATN from hypoperfusion in setting of
   sepsis.
   - f/u renal recs
   - monitor lytes
   # C.diff: Diagnosed in setting of abdominal pain and relatively soon
   interval development of septic picture.
   - cont with IV flagyl (d1=[**3-21**]; day 14)
   - surgery following
   # AML/Leukemia cutis:  S/p dacogen.
   - tx to keep HCT>25 based on consultation with surgery
   - tx to keep plts >50K (transfuse this AM)
   - BMT reccs
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: on arrival, very tachycardic to
   130-150s.  Likely all response to being septic and post operatively.
   Norepinephrine also likely culprit.  Cards consulted and do not think
   TEE followed by cardioversion indicated at this time. If becomes
   acutely unstable, consider emergent cardioversion without TEE followed
   by amio gtt.  HR stable over last several days.
   - hold nodal agents for now
   - no amio for now- not anticoagulated so concern for embolic even if
   spontaneously converts
   # Sacral deep tissue injury:  Wound nurses following.
   # FEN: NPO for now; IVFs as above; TPN
   - replete lytes PRN
   # Comm: Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4140**]

Summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and a previous duodenal ulcer surgery. He was admitted with leukemia cutis/acute myeloid leukemia (AML), left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and developed acute abdominal pain on [**3-21**]. He underwent a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. The patient continues to have fevers with a wide differential including infection, tumor, etc. His respiratory status has improved post-extubation, and he is maintaining adequate urine output. He is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics and other ICU medications as per the plan.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing sepsis due to persistent infection and duodenal perforation with extravasation of intestinal contents.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient had hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure in the setting of sepsis, which has improved after pleural drain placement and thoracentesis.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient had signs of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) initially but is no longer exhibiting clinical signs of DIC on labs.
4. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient experienced acute tubular necrosis (ATN) with muddy brown casts in urine, likely due to hypoperfusion during septic shock.

   79 year-old male with a history of HTN, HLP, atrial fibrillation, h/o
   duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh
   MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff who developed acute
   abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free air and is now s/p
   right hemicolectomy and ileostomy
   # Septic shock: Presumably due to continued infection and persistent
   duodenal perforation with extravasation of intestinal contents.
   Patient is continuing to have fevers with wide differential including
   infection, tumor, etc.  Overall trend is toward improvement.  We will
   attempt to wean pressors and replete with blood products +/- albumin as
   needed.  CT on [**2157-3-30**] showed persistent duodetal perforation but no
   clear evidence of abscess.   In contact with surgery (pager [**Numeric Identifier 4453**]).
   - Continue broad spectrum abx meropenem d1=[**3-22**] (day 13), metronidazole
   d1=[**3-21**] (day 14), fluconazole d1=[**3-21**] (day 14)
   - ID reccs d/c vancomycin- done
   - albumin and blood products as needed for intravascular volume
   - restart lasix gtt
   - titrate levo PRN
   - Keep Hct>25, Plt.>50
   - Hct, Plt, Coags q12hrs
   # Respiratory Failure: both hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure
   in the setting of sepsis.  CXR with pulmonary edema and pleural
   effusions.  Improved aeration of the left lung after pleural drain
   placement and on right side after thoracentesis.  S/p bronch on [**3-23**]
   for decreased right lung size but mucous plug again absent.  Bronched
   again [**4-1**] w/o clear plugging or collapse.   Extubated successfully on
   [**4-2**].

   # Coagulopathy:  On [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] admission  met parameters for DIC based on
   elevated FDP but not clinically in DIC given absence of diffuse
   bleeding.
   - continue blood, FFP, blood transfusions as needed
   - coags, hct, and platlets q12hr with goal INR<=1.6
   - s/p vitamin K 5mg IV x 2 on [**2157-3-23**]
   # Hemicolectomy and duodenal perforation:  Sepsis management as above,
   transfusion parameters as above. Collaborating with surgical team
   # [**Last Name (un) 2406**]:  ATN with muddy brown casts in urine.  Was oliguric on [**2157-3-22**]
   but urine output increasing as of [**2157-3-23**].  Concern initially for
   worsening kidney function and possible need for dialysis but UOP
   improving.  Likely experienced ATN from hypoperfusion in setting of
   sepsis.
   - f/u renal recs
   - monitor lytes
   # C.diff: Diagnosed in setting of abdominal pain and relatively soon
   interval development of septic picture.
   - cont with IV flagyl (d1=[**3-21**]; day 14)
   - surgery following
   # AML/Leukemia cutis:  S/p dacogen.
   - tx to keep HCT>25 based on consultation with surgery
   - tx to keep plts >50K (transfuse this AM)
   - BMT reccs
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: on arrival, very tachycardic to
   130-150s.  Likely all response to being septic and post operatively.
   Norepinephrine also likely culprit.  Cards consulted and do not think
   TEE followed by cardioversion indicated at this time. If becomes
   acutely unstable, consider emergent cardioversion without TEE followed
   by amio gtt.  HR stable over last several days.
   - hold nodal agents for now
   - no amio for now- not anticoagulated so concern for embolic even if
   spontaneously converts
   # Sacral deep tissue injury:  Wound nurses following.
   # FEN: NPO for now; IVFs as above; TPN

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension (HTN), hyperlipidemia (HLP), atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer surgery. He was admitted with leukemia cutis/acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and left thigh MRSA cellulitis. The patient developed acute abdominal pain and underwent a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy due to concerns for free air on CT scan. He also had an episode of Clostridium difficile (c.diff) infection. The patient experienced septic shock, respiratory failure, coagulopathy, acute tubular necrosis (ATN), and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR). The patient's current plan includes continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics, blood product transfusions, diuresis, and titrating pressor support as needed. The patient's code status is do not resuscitate (DNR) / do not intubate (DNI).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient has a history of multiple infections, including MRSA cellulitis, c.diff, and possible ongoing infection related to the duodenal perforation. This increases the risk of sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient had hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure and required mechanical ventilation. There is a possibility of recurrent respiratory failure if the patient develops another lung infection or if there is a deterioration in lung function

The patient was admitted with leukemia cutis/acute myeloid leukemia (AML), left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and a hospital course complicated by Clostridium difficile (c.diff) infection. The patient recently underwent a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy.

The patient is currently experiencing several medical complications, including septic shock due to continued infection and persistent duodenal perforation with extravasation of intestinal contents. The patient also has respiratory failure, both hypercarbic and hypoxemic, in the setting of sepsis. There is pulmonary edema and pleural effusions on chest X-ray, which improved after pleural drain placement and thoracentesis. The patient was successfully extubated on [**4-2**].

The patient also has a coagulopathy, which was initially suspected to be disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) but is now resolved. The patient's kidney function initially worsened, leading to acute tubular necrosis (ATN), but has since improved. The patient has a diagnosis of Clostridium difficile infection and is being treated with IV flagyl.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer surgery. He was admitted with leukemia cutis/acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and left thigh MRSA cellulitis. During his hospital course, he developed Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection and subsequently underwent a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. The patient's current condition is septic shock, likely due to continued infection and persistent duodenal perforation with extravasation of intestinal contents. He has also had a sacral deep tissue injury and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Septic Shock: The patient is currently experiencing septic shock, which is a life-threatening condition caused by an overwhelming infection. It can lead to organ dysfunction and failure if not promptly managed.

2. Duodenal Perforation: The patient has a persistent duodenal perforation from a previous duodenal ulcer surgery. This can lead to further complications such as abscess formation, peritonitis, or sepsis if not addressed properly.

3. C. difficile Infection: The patient has been diagnosed with C. difficile infection, which can cause severe diarrhea and colitis. It can lead to complications such as dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, and sepsis if left untreated.

4. AML/Leukemia Cutis: The patient has leukemia cutis/acute myeloid leukemia (AML), which is a type of blood cancer. It can spread to the skin and other organs, leading to various complications depending on the extent of the disease progression.

5. MRSA Cellulitis: The patient initially presented with left thigh MRSA cellulitis, which is a bacterial skin infection caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. If not properly managed, it can lead to worsening infection, sepsis, or the development of resistant strains of bacteria.

6. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which is an irregular heart rhythm. It can increase the risk of blood clots, stroke, and heart failure if not managed appropriately.

7. Sacral Deep Tissue Injury: The patient has a sacral deep tissue injury, which can lead to complications such as infection, non-healing wounds, or pressure ulcers if not managed properly.

Overall, the patient's complex medical history and current condition pose several potential medical complications that require close monitoring and appropriate management.

Summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer surgery. He was admitted with leukemia cutis/acute myeloid leukemia (AML), left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and had a hospital course complicated by Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection. The patient underwent a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. 

The patient's current condition is summarized as follows:
- Vital signs: The patient's temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), heart rate is 108 beats per minute, blood pressure is 89/60 mmHg (75/33-120/65), respiratory rate is 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 96%. The patient has atrial fibrillation.
- General appearance: The patient is not in acute distress.
- Eyes/conjunctiva: Extremities: Peripheral vascular: Skin: Neurologic: Follows simple commands, responds to movement, tone not assessed.
- Labs/radiology: The patient has elevated white blood cell count, hematocrit, platelets, and lactic acid levels. There are also abnormal results for electrolytes, kidney function tests, liver function tests, and coagulation profile.
- Assessment and plan: The patient has multiple medical complications including septic shock, respiratory failure, coagulopathy, hemicolectomy and duodenal perforation, acute tubular necrosis (ATN), Clostridium difficile infection, acute myeloid leukemia/leukemia cutis, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and sacral deep tissue injury. The patient's current management includes broad-spectrum antibiotics, blood product transfusions, and close monitoring of vital signs, electrolytes, coagulation parameters, and organ function. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening septic shock, respiratory failure, coagulopathy, kidney injury, C. difficile infection recurrence, leukemia progression, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and wound infection or dehiscence at the surgical site.

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension (HTN), hyperlipidemia (HLP), atrial fibrillation, and a history of duodenal ulcer surgery. He was admitted with leukemia cutis/acute myeloid leukemia (AML), left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and c.diff infection. The patient underwent a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. 

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.2°C (98.9°F), heart rate of 95 bpm, blood pressure of 76/44 mmHg, respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 92%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 550 mL, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and PEEP of 10 cmH2O.

The patient's lab results show a white blood cell count of 7.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.1 g/dL, platelet count of 44 K/uL, sodium of 143 mg/dL, potassium of 4.3 mEq/L, chloride of 110 mEq/L, magnesium of 2.1 mg/dL, and blood glucose of 158 mg/dL. The results also indicate an elevated lactic acid level of 1.7 mmol/L and a decreased albumin level of 2.5 g/dL. 

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, eyes/conjunctiva showing eyes moving in all directions (EMI), and peripheral vascular pulses present but not assessed. The patient's extremities are edematous in both arms, and the skin is not assessed. Neurologically, the patient follows simple commands and responds appropriately.

The patient's medical conditions include septic shock, coagulopathy, hemicolectomy and duodenal perforation, C.diff infection, AML/leukemia cutis, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and sacral deep tissue injury.

The plan of care includes setting up home with hospice, weaning off pressors, repleting with blood products, monitoring intravascular volume, discontinuing lasix, off levo, and maintaining hemoglobin concentration above 25% and platelet count above 50 K/uL. The patient's family wants to take him home for the remaining time he has left, and the plan is for a bereavement counselor to coordinate with hospice.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Continued septic shock due to ongoing infection and persistent duodenal perforation.
2. Bleeding due to coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia.
3. Kidney injury due to hypotension and decreased renal perfusion.
4. Malnutrition due to ileostomy and inability to tolerate oral intake.
5. Respiratory failure due to pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia.
6. Deep vein thrombosis due to immobility and central venous catheters.
7. Pressure ulcers due to prolonged immobility and decreased tissue perfusion.
8. Arrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia.

These potential complications should be closely monitored and managed accordingly to ensure the patient's comfort and quality of life during the remaining time he has left.
